Description: Mould-made scarab in Egyptian blue; quite detailed back with modelled clypeus, prothorax and elytra indicated by incised lines; view at side unknown; underside incised with a crude representation of a palm tree (or central sceptre?) flanked by two standing figures (monkeys or men?); pierced lenghtwise; eroded surfaces.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This scarab belongs to a type which was produced at the 'Scarab Factory' (on its various productions see Webb forthcoming) and was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, particularly in Eastern Greece, and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 121-127, type XXXIV, subtype B1-17, see especially B17 for this piece). For a similar type of motif on a scaraboid from Naukratis: BM 1886,0401.1685. Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 123-124, type XXXIV B17)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OE.26) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5766 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
